intro: Cortusa mongolica, commonly known as the Mongolian bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Mongolia and northern China. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its striking blue to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or alpine environments. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
